metadata.case_name: Benares Ice Factory Ltd. & Ors. v. New Bheerbhum Coal Co. Ltd. & Anr.

facts.text: In Suit No. 1024 of 1953 on the Original Side of the Calcutta High Court, a decree for Rs. 18,497-15-0 was passed by consent in favour of New Bheerbhum Coal Co. Ltd. (respondent 1) and against Benares Ice Factory, Ltd. (appellant 2) on December 5, 1955.

The decree provided for payment by six equal instalments and directed that in case of default of any instalment, the balance would become payable. A first charge was created on the plant and machinery of appellant 2.
Default occurred in payment of instalments; respondent 1 applied for execution on April 10, 1956.
Interim order appointing Mr. A. K. Sen as Receiver of the properties charged made on May 17, 1956.
Appointment of receiver confirmed on May 30, 1956, with liberty to sell properties by private treaty or public auction.
Receiver took possession of the property in December 1956.
Receiver entered into agreement with Sukhlal Amarchand Vadnagra (respondent 2) for sale of property for Rs. 30,000 on March 10, 1958.
Agreement provided that purchaser to deposit Rs. 30,000 within one month of intimation that sale confirmed by High Court.
Respondent 1 applied for confirmation of agreement on March 31, 1958.

G.K. Mitter J. allowed application on May 9, 1958: appellants to deposit Rs. 3,000 with attorneys of decree holder, and balance decretal amount within 10 weeks; in default, sale to respondent 2 confirmed.
Appellants deposited Rs. 3,000 on May 30, 1958, and had paid Rs. 3,500 to receiver in August 1957.
Appellant 2 applied to cancel agreement and extend time; dismissed by G.K. Mitter J. on July 29, 1958, confirming sale.
Appellant 2 applied on August 20, 1958, for leave to deposit balance decretal amount and restrain receiver from receiving money from purchaser.
Respondent 2 tendered cheque for Rs. 30,000 on August 22, 1958, took it back and paid cash on September 1, 1958.
Application of appellant 2 dismissed by G.K. Mitter J. on September 4, 1958; stay of possession for one week.
Appeal filed to Division Bench; stay of delivery pending appeal.
Division Bench dismissed appeal on April 29, 1959; refused certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.
Special leave granted by Supreme Court on May 20, 1959.
Receiver appointed with powers under O. 40 r. 1(d) CPC, liberty to sell by private treaty or auction before August 13, 1956.

legal_issues.text: Whether the provisions of O. 21, r. 89 of the Code of Civil Procedure apply to a sale held by a receiver appointed by the court and authorized to sell the property in question.
Whether the High Court should have considered relief under s. 151 CPC.
Whether the sale had not been properly confirmed before the application for leave to pay decretal amount.

petitioner_arguments.text: Courts below erred in refusing relief under O. 21 r. 89 on ground that it was inapplicable to sale by receiver.
High Court should have considered prayer under s. 151 CPC as appellants were able to pay balance decretal amount.
Sale was conditional subject to court confirmation; court could refuse confirmation when appellants applied to pay decretal amount.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S.M. Sudevi Devi v. Sovaram Agarwallah (1906) 10 C.W.N. 306

respondent_arguments.text: O. 21 r. 89 inapplicable to receiver's sale; appellants had sufficient opportunities to pay but defaulted.

court_reasoning.text: Receiver appointed in execution under s. 51 CPC with powers under O. 40 r. 1(d); sale by receiver is mode of execution, governed by O. 40, not attracting O. 21 provisions prima facie.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appointment of receiver is itself a mode of execution; powers under O. 40 r. 1(d) exercised in selling property.

court_reasoning.text: O. 21 r. 66 (proclamation) inapplicable to receiver sales as court does not order public auction sale; thus second condition of O. 21 r. 89(1)(b) inapplicable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No proclamation required for receiver sales; O. 21 r. 89 wholly inapplicable.

court_reasoning.text: No interference under s. 151 as appellants had multiple opportunities to pay but defaulted repeatedly.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Courts below correctly refused discretionary relief.

court_reasoning.text: Order of May 9, 1958 was composite, not conditional; provided for confirmation on default.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No scope to apply principle from S.M. Sudevi Devi case.

holdings.text: Provisions of O. 21 r. 89 do not apply to sales held by receivers appointed in execution proceedings.
No relief under s. 151 CPC warranted due to repeated defaults by appellants.
Sale properly confirmed; order of May 9, 1958 was composite, not conditional.

precedents_cited.case_name: S.M. Sudevi Devi v. Sovaram Agarwallah
precedents_cited.relevance: Dealt with inherent power to set aside ex parte order in conditional decree; not applicable as order here was composite.

precedents_cited.case_name: Minatoonnessa Bibee Ors. v. Khatoonnessa Bibee Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Held receiver sales similar to court sales attracting O. 21; observations not to be read as general proposition.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gulam Hossein Cassim Ariff v. Fatima Begum
precedents_cited.relevance: Receiver sale not a sale by court; no sale certificate or confirmation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jogemaya Dasee v. Akhoy Coomar Das
precedents_cited.relevance: Sale by Commissioner of Partition not by court.

precedents_cited.case_name: Basir Ali v. Hafiz Nazir Ali
precedents_cited.relevance: Purchaser must satisfy title; sales certificate evidences transfer.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rani Bala Bose v. Hirendra Chandra Ghose
precedents_cited.relevance: Preferred view of Sale J. but obiter.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: O. 21 r. 89 inapplicable to receiver sales; receiver powers under s. 51, O. 40 r. 1(d); no proclamation under O. 21 r. 66 needed.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court correct in holding O. 21 r. 89 inapplicable to receiver's sale and refusing relief under s. 151; no interference warranted.

key_quotes.text: The principal question which this appeal by special leave raises for our decision is Whether the provisions of s. 21, r. 89 of the Code of Civil Procedure apply to a sale held by a receiver appointed by the court and authorized to sell the property in question.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: In our opinion there can be no doubt that the provisions of the said rule do not apply to sales held by receivers.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on inapplicability of O. 21 r. 66 and thus r. 89.

key_quotes.text: We are, therefore, satisfied that the High Court was right in refusing to entertain the appellants application under O. 21, r. 89.
key_quotes.speaker: court
